unnormalised: Healthcare in India is a pretty diverse field, right? You've got everyone from the ward boys to the top-notch surgeons. But figuring out who does what can sometimes be a bit of a head-scratcher. Like, what’s the difference between Dr. Sharma and Prof. Verma? Both are doctors, but one teaches, maybe?
normalised: Healthcare in India is a pretty diverse field, right? You have everyone from the ward boys to the top-notch surgeons. But figuring out who does what can sometimes be a bit of a head-scratcher. Like, what's the difference between Doctor Sharma and Professor Verma? Both are doctors, but one teaches, maybe?

unnormalised: First off, "Dr." is pretty universal. If someone's got that title, it usually means they've got an MBBS degree, or maybe a BDS if they're a dentist. Then you have super-specialists, people who’ve done their MD or MS after their MBBS. It gets even more interesting after that, like when Dr. Kapoor decided to pursue his DM in Cardiology. That's like, super-duper specialization.
normalised: First off, "Doctor" is pretty universal. If someone's got that title, it usually means they have an M-B-B-S degree, or maybe a B-D-S if they're a dentist. Then you have super-specialists, people who have done their M-D or M-S after their M-B-B-S. It gets even more interesting after that, like when Doctor Kapoor decided to pursue his D-M in Cardiology. That's like, super-duper specialization.

unnormalised: Now, about Prof. Verma – that "Prof." bit? That generally means they're a professor at a medical college. They probably still see patients, but a big part of their job is teaching future doctors. So, someone like Prof. Desai at AIIMS might be teaching orthopedic surgery alongside his practice. You might also see titles like "Asst. Prof." or "Assoc. Prof.," depending on where they are in their academic career.

unnormalised: Then there are other titles. Say you meet someone called "Sr. Resident Dr. Patel" at a hospital. That means they’re further along in their residency, almost finished with their specialization. You might also see "Consultant Dr. Singh" – that means they’re a qualified specialist who consults at the hospital, maybe not a full-time employee. It's like a whole ecosystem of titles, ya?

unnormalised: So, next time you're at a hospital or clinic, take a look at the names on the doors. Understanding those little abbreviations before their names can actually tell you a lot about their training and experience. Just remember, they’re all there to help you get better!
